column1: Nuevo Laredo (Spanish pronunciation: [ˈnweβo laˈɾeðo]) is a city in the Municipality of Nuevo Laredo in the Mexican state of Tamaulipas. The city lies on the banks of the Rio Grande
column2: across from the American city of the same name. The 2010 census population of the city was 373
column3: 725. Nuevo Laredo is part of the Laredo-Nuevo Laredo Metropolitan Area with a population of 636
column4: 516. The municipality has an area of 1
column5: 334.02 km2 (515.07 sq mi). Both the city and the municipality rank as the third largest in the state.

column1: The city is connected to Laredo
column2: Texas by three international bridges and a rail bridge. The city is larger and younger than its American counterpart. As an indication of its economic importance
column3: one of Mexico's banderas monumentales is in the city (these banderas have been established in state capitals and cities of significance).

column1: == History ==

Nuevo Laredo was part of the territory of the original settlement of Laredo (now in Texas) which was founded in 1755 by the Spaniard Don Tomás Sánchez in the northern part of the Rio Grande. The settlement's territory was granted to José de Escandón by the King of Spain
column2: and the settlement's territory and population remained unified for ninety years
column3: until the war of 1846–1848

column1: Early in 1848
column2: the Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo divided the territory attached to Laredo between the United States (specifically
column3: Texas) and Mexico. Nuevo Laredo was founded on June 15
column5: by seventeen Laredo families who wished to remain Mexican and therefore moved to the Mexican side of the Rio Grande. They identified with Mexico
column8: and decided to keep their Mexican citizenship. The founders of Nuevo Laredo even took with them the bones of their ancestors so they would continue to rest in Mexican ground.

column1: === Drug-related violence ===
As a border town
column2: Nuevo Laredo is known for its turf war in which drug cartels compete for control of the drug trade into the United States. Nuevo Laredo is a lucrative drug corridor because of the large volume of trucks that pass through the area
column3: and the multiple exploitable ports of entry.Nuevo Laredo is the base of Los Zetas
column4: originally the armed wing of the Gulf Cartel; the two organizations separated in early 2010 and have been fighting for the control of the smuggling routes to the United States. As of 2012
column5: Los Zetas are thought to be Mexico's largest criminal organization. Drug violence involving the Sinaloa and Gulf Cartels escalated in 2003
column6: when the city was controlled by the Gulf Cartel. 2012 has seen an unprecedented series of mass murder attacks in the city between the Sinaloa Cartel and Gulf Cartel on one side and Los Zetas on the other.

column1: == Geography ==

Nuevo Laredo is in the northern tip of Tamaulipas on the west end of the Rio Grande Plains. Rio Grande is the only source that supplies its citizens with water. El Coyote Creek supplies Nuevo Laredo's only natural lake El Laguito (The Small Lake).  The area consists of a few hills and flat land covered with grass
column2: oak
column3: and mesquite.

column1: == Climate ==
Nuevo Laredo features a semi-arid climate. Nuevo Laredo's weather is influenced by its proximity to the Chihuahuan Desert to the west
column2: by the Sierra Madre Oriental mountains to the south and west
column3: and by the Gulf of Mexico to the east.  Much of the moisture from the Pacific is blocked by the Sierra Madre Oriental.  Therefore
column4: most of the moisture derives from the Gulf of Mexico.  Its geographic location causes Nuevo Laredo's weather to range from long periods of heat to sudden violent storms in a short period of time. Nuevo Laredo is cold for Tamaulipas standards during winter
column5: the average daytime highs are around 66 °F (18.9 °C) and overnight lows around 43 °F (6.1 °C); although it is rare for snow to fall in Nuevo Laredo
column6: there was actually snow on the ground for a few hours on the morning of Christmas Day 2004.

column1: Nuevo Laredo experiences an average high temperature of about 99 °F (37.2 °C)
column2: and an average low of about 75 °F (23.9 °C) during summer
column3: and 20 inches (508 mm) of rain per year. As Laredo sometimes undergoes  drought
column4: a water conservation ordinance was implemented in 2003.

column1: == Government ==
Nuevo Laredo is governed by an elected Cabildo
column2: which is composed of the Presidente Municipal (Municipal President or Mayor)
column3: two Síndicos
column4: and twenty Regidores. The PAN is in control of the city government. The Mayor is in charge of the municipal administration. The Síndicos supervise the municipal budget and expenditures
column5: and the Regidores are elected by the party.

column1: === Public safety ===
Public safety is provided by three municipal departments: (1) municipal police (Dirección de Seguridad Ciudadana)
column2: (2) traffic control (Dirección de Seguridad Vial)
column3: and (3) the emergency services department (Dirección de Protección Civil
column4: Bomberos y Desastres).As well as the State Police Force Tamaulipas ("Fuerza Tamaulipas") replacing former Acreditable State Police ("Polícia Estatal Acreditable")

column1: Because of the drug-related violence
column2: Federal level departments take part in the security effort
column3: SEDENA Military Police ("Polícia Military") Mexican Army Troops
column4: SEMAR Mexican Navy Troops and Federal Police.

column1: == Economy ==
Nuevo Laredo (along with Laredo
column2: Texas) is the most important trade border crossing of Latin America (approximately 8500 trucks cross the border each day). Its geographical position has enabled this city to grow and specialize in the international trade business. Nuevo Laredo has a very developed logistics and transportation industry
column3: complemented with a variety of hotel chains
column4: restaurants and a cultural center where events such as the Tamaulipas International Festival take place.

column1: Nuevo Laredo is on the primary trade route connecting Canada
column2: the United States and Mexico. Both Nuevo Laredo and Laredo
column3: Texas are now the gateway to Mexico's burgeoning industrial complex
column6: which both business and industry cannot find anywhere else. Nuevo Laredo is the only Mexico/U.S. border city strategically positioned at the convergence of all land transportation systems. The main highway and railroad leading from Central Mexico through Mexico City
column8: Saltillo and Monterrey join with two major U.S. rail lines at Nuevo Laredo and major American highway Interstate 35
column9: thus offering fast access to the most important metropolitan areas and seaports of Texas
column10: as well as northern states and Canada. For more than a decade
column11: Mexico's economic policies have greatly increased Mexico/U.S. trade and cross-border production in the Nuevo Laredo area.

column1: There are three bridges in the Nuevo Laredo area:  International Bridge #1 (the oldest); International Bridge #2 (also known as Juarez-Lincoln; no pedestrians); International Bridge #3 (also known as the Free Trade or Libre Comercio Bridge; inaugurated in 1999; cargo only). Also the Colombia-Solidarity (Solidaridad) Bridge (located about 20 miles (32 km) NW of the city in Colombia
column2: Nuevo León). There are no urban areas on either side of this bridge.

column1: Nuevo Laredo is a strategic investment point. On this site there are six recognized industrial parks: Oradel Industrial Center
column2: Longoria Industrial Park
column3: Rio Bravo Industrial Park

column1: == Education ==
The educational infrastructure amounted to 288 school sites which are 71 kindergartens
column2: 148 elementary schools
column3: 34 junior high schools

column1: === Higher education ===
There are twelve universities in Nuevo Laredo. Undergraduate studies normally last at least 3 years
column2: divided into semesters or quarters
column3: depending on the college or university.

column1: Every graduate gets a bachelor's degree (Licenciatura or Ingenieria). Some of these universities also offer postgraduate studies. A "maestría" is a 2-year degree after a bachelor's degree
column2: which awards the title of Master (Maestro).

column1: Universidad Autónoma de Tamaulipas (UAT) It has 2 faculties. The faculty of commerce
column2: administration and social sciences offers bachelor's degrees in: International trade
column3: Computing
column6: and Accountancy. The faculty of nursing offers bachelor's degrees in: Nursing

column1: == Transportation ==
Nuevo Laredo is served by the Quetzalcóatl International Airport with daily flights to Mexico City. The neighboring Laredo International Airport in Laredo
column2: Texas has daily flights to Houston (George Bush Intercontinental Airport) and to Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport and Tri-weekly flights to Las Vegas
column3: Nevada and bi-weekly seasonal (May–August) flights to Orlando

column1: === Mass transit ===

Transporte Urbano de Nuevo Laredo (TUNL) is the mass transit system that operates in Nuevo Laredo with fixed routes with millions of passengers per year. TUNL works with a fleet of fixed-route buses. TUNL hub is located in downtown Nuevo Laredo.

== People and culture ==
=== Parks and zoos ===
Parque Viveros (en:Viveros Park) is a 124-acre (0.50 km2) forest park that overlooks the Rio Grande on the eastern side of Nuevo Laredo. The park features a zoo
column2: two large swimming pools
column3: walking trails
column4: picnic areas with barbecue pits and playgrounds.

column1: === Theaters ===
Nuevo Laredo has three main theaters the "Centro Cultural"
column2: "Teatro de la Ciudad"
column3: and "Casa de Cultura". The Centro Cultural (en:Cultural Center)
column4: is Nuevo Laredo's main theater with a sitting capacity of 1
column5: 200 guests. The theater has presented high level shows high level
column7: concerts and dance recitals. The theater has a museum
column9: and a cafeteria. The Teatro de la Ciudad (en:City Theater) is a theater which presents plays
column11: concerts and musical shows and special events. The Casa de Cultura (en:House of Culture) houses music
column13: dance and literature workshops and also presents major artistic and cultural events such as art exhibitions

column1: === Sports ===
==== Baseball ====

The Tecolotes de Nuevo Laredo (Nuevo Laredo Owls) formally known as the Tecolotes de los Dos Laredos (Owls of the Two Laredos) were a Mexican Baseball League team that played in the Zona Norte (Northern Division) of the Mexican League until 2010. The Ciudad Deportiva was their home Baseball park which had a capacity of 12
column2: 000 fans. The Tecolotes returned to Nuevo Laredo
column3: Tamaulipas for the 2008 season after a 4 years absence in the city when the team was transferred to Tijuana and renamed Potros de Tijuana (Tijuana Colts). The Rieleros from Aguascalientes were transferred to Nuevo Laredo as the Tecolotes de Nuevo Laredo. The Tecolotes were the Mexican League Champions in 1953

column1: The Parque la Junta (La Junta Park) was opened in 1947 and has a capacity of 6
column2: 000 people. The stadium was the home to the five-time champion Mexican Baseball League team Tecolotes de los Dos Laredos (The Owls of the Two Laredos) from 1947 to 2003. In 2019 the stadium was refurbished to once again host the Tecolotes.

column1: ==== Football ====

The Bravos de Nuevo Laredo is a football club in the Tercera División in Nuevo Laredo. The Unidad Deportiva Benito Juárez (Benito Juárez Sport Complex) is their home stadium. The Bravos are an institution formed in 2004 by a groups of business people in Nuevo Laredo
column2: whose objective is to organize a football team in the city with aspirations it will become a professional football club.  This has been the first team to have all of their games transmitted live via internet through www.arcanasa.com up to the end of the 2010 tournament.The Ciudad Deportiva (Sports City) is a sports complex built in 2007 which main feature is a baseball park in Nuevo Laredo
column3: Mexico. It is home to the Tecolotes de Nuevo Laredo Mexican Baseball League team.  The Ciudad Deportiva can seat up to 12
column4: 000 fans at a baseball game. Phase one of this project has been completed which only included the Baseball Park. Phase II of this project will include a new soccer stadium within Mexican Primera Division standards for a possible expansion of one of its teams to Nuevo Laredo. Phase II also includes a gym that will seat 1

column1: ==== Basketball ====
The Toros de Nuevo Laredo is a basketball team in Nuevo Laredo
column2: playing in the Mexican professional league Liga Nacional de Baloncesto Profesional (LNBP). The Toros de Nuevo Laredo play in the Ciudad Deportiva Indoor Stadium. They entered the league in 2009 to join the North Conference. Prior to the Toros de Nuevo Laredo
column3: Nuevo Laredo had the Venados de Nuevo Laredo which played on the LNBP for the 2007–2008 season.

Historical Archive. In it lies the documentary and graphic memory of the city, also has temporary exhibitions, consultation area, audiovisual area and the site museum which displays railroad artifacts, photographs and documents of time alluding to the history of the Railroad in Nuevo Laredo.

Narciso Mendoza park. It has the Fidel Cuellar library, a walking trail around the park (circuit almost 800 m), a FutRap court and a playground .

Recreational park El Laguito.
Polyforum Dr. Rodolfo Torre Cantu.  Place to hold events and mass entertainment, was opened on September 4, 2013. It has the capacity to hold over 5,000 people and parking for over 1,000 vehicles. The project is still under construction and includes a civic center, stage performances, cultural walk, aquarium, soccer fields and basketball courts and more.There is a fairly large array of night-time entertainment venues. Most establishments (clubs, bars, and restaurants) are located in the historical district.  Other restaurants (including chains such as Carl's Jr., Burger King, Kentucky Fried Chicken, and McDonald's) are located along Avenida Vicente Guerrero and Avenida Reforma. Nuevo Laredo has a red light district called Boy's Town, (or La Zona").
